name: TIM
rom: 1024 byte TIM monitor in 6530, 1024 byte in 2708 EPROM
ports: Front 2708 eprom burner, BNC analog output, rear RS232
description:
The TIM (Terminal Interface Monitor) was a MOS Technology Inc's build-it-yourself 6502 development system that was launched before the KIM-1.
When a computer fan ordered a TIM from MOS Technology in Norristown, Pennsylvania, he got a MCS6530-004 (1k TIM monitor program in ROM), and a manual (15 sheets of 11x17 folded & stapled in the middle) containing a suggested schematic, the TIM monitor commands, and listing. He had to provide himself with various components, including the MOS MSC6502 processor.

Thanks to Jeffrey R. Owen, the owner of the pictured system, who relates us:
When the KIM-1 was announced in 1975, my order was immediately placed.  The price was US$150. I received a KIM-1 with serial number 285.  The 6502 at that time did NOT have the ROR instruction.
About a year later, seeking more flexibility and wanting to use the newly added 'ROR' instruction, I purchased a TIM,an MCS6502
with the 'ROR' instruction, and two MCS6532's.
I constructed a simple computer, much like the one in the TIM manual, on a kludge board.  No box, it was powered by a lab supply.  Features and circuits were added, and removed as required.  Mounting it in the brown box with power supply was done in 1979, oneof the last modifications. It was then a small development system including a 2708 PROM burner (ZIF socket outside box), and a three position switch selecting the memory map presented after reset.
I gave my KIM-1 to a friend in Teheran when we left Iran in September 1978.  I kept the TIM which was just a circuit board at the time.  We left Iran by taking a train to Moscow, then another to Belgium. When leaving the USSR, the customs officer looked at the board, and called a specialist, who quickly identified every chip and indicated that there was no problem.
Long after it had ceased to be a development system, the TIM served as a printer switch, allowing three computers to share a printer, and using A 2708 EPROM containing the printer switch application code in the ZIF socket.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>A minimalist version!<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Power supply status<br> <b>(2)</b> LEDs under program control<br> <b>(3)</b> Vents for cooling!<br> <b>(4)</b> 3-position switch. Sets which memory device will be mapped to top memory upon next reset (6502 vectors in top memory) usually with application code.<br> <b>(5)</b> Reset switch<br> <b>(6)</b> BNC connector. Analog/Digital converter output<br> <b>(7)</b> 2708 EPROM on ZIF socket. Only 2708 version could be programmed  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> EPROM BURNER</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Zero Insertion Force (ZIF) socket for 2708 EPROM<br> <b>(2)</b> 2708 Eprom programmer circuitry. Software routines are contained in the internal Eprom, allowing copy 2708 into ZIF socket to internal RAM or program external 2708 from data in RAM.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOS CHIPS AREA</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 6502 processor. When initially built, this board used a 6502 without the ROR instruction. There were enough complaints that MOS technology added it. This 6502 was replaced when the new version became available<br> <b>(2)</b> 6530-004. This IC contains 64 bytes of RAM, 1024 bytes of ROM (TIM monitor), a timer and 16 I/O lines.<br> <b>(3)</b> 2 x 6532 general purpose I/O chips. Each had 128 Byte RAM, a timer and two 8-bit bidirectional ports.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ROM AND RAM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Internal 2708 EPROM. Contains utility subroutines, eg Burn EPROM.<br> Note the three high stacked RAM chips! Each one is 2114 - 1024 x 4 bit. Chip select pins on other side are only pins not common to all three layers. </blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl !  Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991.  <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems so happy to have an Hit-Bit...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID SITUATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>A translation would be : "the 10 years old and more children appreciate quickly the computing principles and have a lot of fun with their ZX-80" <br><br> So they say...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT FS II, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is for the Micromachine 4000, but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this funky ??!! I love it. We can see here the handle  of the H1.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>...released in "l'Ordinateur Individuel" magazine n°12<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Fabien Neck and its <a href="http://www.system-cfg.com/" target="_blank">website</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH (STUPID) PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Family life scene in front of a complete Atmos system carefully lined up on the coffee table in the living room, with a minimum of visible cables. <br><br> The flaw?... No, it is not that it is rather difficult to use such a serious configuration for hours sitting on the floor. The flaw comes rather from the photographer who forgot to do the housework before taking the picture and left to posterity his accessories cartons right behind the low dresser.</blockquote>

media: 2708 in front socket can be written (programmed) and read
